title: Imposing Duties To Address the Synthetic Opioid Supply Chain in the People's Republic of China
summary:
The document is Executive Order 14195, issued by President Donald J. Trump on February 1, 2025, which imposes duties to address the synthetic opioid supply chain originating from the People's Republic of China (PRC). The order highlights the severe impact of synthetic opioids, particularly fentanyl, on American society, causing approximately 200 deaths daily and straining healthcare systems.

The President emphasizes that the PRC, under the control of the Chinese Communist Party, has facilitated the export of fentanyl and precursor chemicals, while also providing support to transnational criminal organizations involved in drug trafficking. Despite previous efforts to curb this crisis through dialogue, the PRC has not taken adequate action to halt the flow of these drugs.

To combat this ongoing national emergency, the Executive Order imposes a 10% ad valorem tariff on all products from the PRC, effective February 4, 2025, unless specific conditions are met for exemptions. The order also allows for increased duties if the PRC retaliates against U.S. exports.

The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with monitoring PRC actions and reporting on their cooperation regarding the opioid crisis. The order stipulates that the tariffs will remain until sufficient measures are taken by the PRC to address the issue. Overall, this Executive Order reflects a significant escalation in U.S. efforts to combat the opioid epidemic linked to foreign supply chains.
